citation.article-title: Taxonomic studies on Arthrobacter nicotianae and related taxa: description of Arthrobacter uratoxydans sp. nov. and Arthrobacter sulfureus sp. nov. and reclassification of Brevibacterium protophormiae as Arthrobacter protophormiae comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Arthrobacter sulfureus sp. nov.
Arthrobacter sulfureus (sul.fu're.us L. adj. sulfureus of sulfur, meaning sulfur-colored)

The description given below is taken from the orignal descriprion of 'Brevibacterium sulfureum' (lizuka and Komagata, 1965) and supplemented with data on the menaquinone, fatty acid and polar lipid composition (Collins and Kropppenstedt, 1983), peptidoglycan (Schleifer and Kandleler, 1972), cell wall sugars (Keddie and Cure, 1976) and own data on the DNA G +C content and physiological studies.
In young cultures rod shaped cells, irregular, 0.4 to 0.6 by 1.2 to 1.6 μm, angular or slightly curved, occasionally club-shaped; snapping divisions are observed.
In old cultures rods become shorter, in some strains coccoid cells are dominating.
Gram-positive.
Motile with peritrichous flagella or non-motile.
Colonies large, circular, smooth, entire, raised, glistening, dull, yellow, opaque, butyrous; 1-3 mm in diameter.
In nutrient broth slightly turbid; in glutamate broth moderate growth, turbid.
In nutrient gelatine stab liquification.
Nitrate reduced to nitrite; indol not produced; hydrolysis of starch and casein negative; acctyl-methyl carbinol not produced; catalase positive.
No acid or gas from glycerol, xylose, glucose, sucrose, lactose, dextrine and starch.

Utilization of a great variety of organic compounds: besides those listed in the footnote to Table 5, the following compounds are assimilate: 4-hydroxybenzoate, L-leucine, L-asparagine, L-arginine and L-histidine; 2 of three strains assimilate 5-aminovalerate, malonate, laevulinate, D-ribose, D-galactose, D-xylitole and 2,3-butylenglycol.
Cellulose nor attacked.
The peptide subunit consists of alanine, D-glutamic acid and lysine.
The interpeptide bridge consists of glutamic acid (Lys-Glu-type, variation A3α:, according to Schleifer and Kandler, 1972).
Cell walls contain galactose and traces of mannose (only one strain tested).
The long chain fatty acids (two strains tested) are primarily of the iso, anteiso, straight chain and unsaturated acid types, with the anteiso 12-methyl tetradecanoic acid (anteiso C15:0) dominating.
The major respiratory isoprenoid Quinones are unsaturated menaquinones either with 9 or with equal amounts of 9 and 10 isoprene units.
Polar lipids consists of phosphatidylglycerol and diphosphatidylglyccrol and of unidentified glycolipids.
Optimal temperature for growth between 25 and 30°C-Optimal pH for growth between 7.0 and 8.0.
No growth at pH 5.0.
Aerobic.
G + C content of the DNA ranges from 64.5 to 66 mol%..
Habait: Soil.
The type strain was isolated from an oil brine.
Type strain: Arthrobacter sulfureus ATCC 19098 (DSM 20167).
